section.name: Project Structure
section.p:
Hippo ECM is a Maven 2 project consisting of
multiple modules which are hierarchically organized as shown below, each module produces exactly one artifact (file). Modules come in four flavors, depending on the type of artifact they create.

li.p: JAR projects create a jar file that can be used in applications.
WAR projects create a web application (a war file) that can be deployed in a servlet server (tomcat, jetty etc.).
EAR projects create an enterprise application (an ear file) that can be deployed in an application server (glassfish, weblogic etc.).
POM projects act as 'glue' for binding together other projects, they don't create anything themselves

section.name: Why so many projects?
section.p: The large number of projects is a direct consequence of the fact that Hippo ECM has been designed from the ground up for customizability and extendability as described in the plugin documentation. The repository and frontend engines that make up the core of Hippo ECM don't implement much functionality themselves. All 'userland' functionality is implemented by plugins that are loaded by the engines. See the chapter on Bootstrapping the repository for further information about this subject.

section.name: Addon
section.p: Plugins are bundled in so called addons which are simple Jar projects under the 'addon' directory.

ul.li: cms is a bundling of all frontend addons that together make up the main functional blocks of the default CMS. Each tab (perspective) in the CMS user interface has it's own addon.
defaultcontent is a repository addon containing some simple sample content meant for demonstration purposes

reporting is a bundling of a repository addon and a frontend addon which together implement reporting functionality for the CMS. Usage examples of this addon are the activity and todo views on the cms-dashboard

reviewed-action is a workflow addon, it implements all business and GUI logic around document lifecycle: reviewing, (un)publishing etc. It is a bundling of three addons and a test project: a repository addon implementing the business logic, a frontend addon bundling some frontend plugins for user interaction and a common addon for the interface between the two.

builtin is also a workflow addon, it differs from other workflow addons in the fact that the server-side implementation is implemented by the repository engine itself instead of in a separate Jar like with a normal addon. Note that these builtin workflow steps are very generic and low-level and should not be accessed directly. They should only be called indirectly from other workflow plugins as part of a chain of workflow steps.

standards-frontend contains a collection of shared frontend plugins. For instance, all cms-* addons contain a Perspective plugin (BrowsePerspective, EditPerspective, ...), so it makes sense to have a common baseclass in standards-frontend.
template is a frontend addon that implements the document template editor
versioning is a frontend addon that contains plugins for interacting with document versioning implemented by the repository
xinha and xinha-frontend are frontend addons that together make up the Xinha HTML editor.
yui is a frontend addon implementing Drag&Drop functionality and other javascript magic.

subsection.name: Dependencies between addons
subsection.p:
Because addons are ordinary java projects built with Maven it is extremely easy to add any inter-addon Java dependency that may seem nessessary. If left unchecked this can easily lead to a situation where all addons depend on each other. When this happens the whole idea of splitting functionality between addons becomes obsolete and we might as well put all plugins into one big addon, or better yet into the engines themselves and reduce the number of projects drastically. Obviously this will also kill all customizability and extendability.
On the other hand completely forbidding all inter-addon dependencies goes to far because it prohibits code reuse. A middle way is to keep these dependencies to a minimum and stick to some simple guidelines:

ol.li: Repository addons should NEVER directly depend on each other via a Java dependency. Even in the case of one workflow calling another this is not done by a direct Java call, but via 'workflow chaining' which is core repository functionality.

As a general rule a dependency 'via the repository' is preferred (by far) over a direct Java dependency. Examples of this kind of dependency are the displaying of Xinha editors by the template editor and the use of the reporting addon by the cms dashboard.

If there's no other way frontend addons MAY directly depend on each other: Examples are the yui-frontend addon that contains wicket behaviours that perform all kinds of javascript magic that many application plugins would very much like to use, and the standards-frontend addon which acts as a parking place for oftenly used, shared frontend code that doesn't really belong in the frontend engine itself.

subsection.p: To make a long story short: Currently there are very few Java dependencies between addons and we're planning to keep it that way.

subsection.name: Finding your way
subsection.p: In order to help you find your way some simple naming conventions are used:

ul.li: The maven artifactId matches the project directory layout
Wicket frontend classes in frontend plugin addon-foo-bar are in package org.hippoecm.frontend.plugins.foo.bar
